Sure, I'd be happy to provide some advice on how to make a strong application for an undergraduate research position in computer science and engineering at the University of Alberta! Here are some tips:

1. Research the research program: Before applying, research the research program and the faculty members involved in it. This will give you a better understanding of the research goals, the focus of the program, and the faculty members' expertise.

2. Prepare a strong resume and cover letter: This step is crucial because it's the first thing the faculty members will see about you. Highlight any relevant coursework, projects, or experience that demonstrates your passion and interest in computer science and engineering. You can also discuss your motivations for applying to the research program in your cover letter.

3. Show your interest and enthusiasm: Faculty members are more likely to take on students who demonstrate interest and enthusiasm for the subject matter. Show your passion through your application materials, and be prepared to communicate your interest in the research project or program during an interview.

4. Emphasize your skills: Highlight the relevant skills you bring to the table that could be useful in the research project or program, such as problem-solving abilities, programming languages, or data analysis skills.

5. Be professional: Treat the application process with professionalism, and make sure to follow all instructions carefully. Follow up with any requested materials or requirements in a timely manner.

6. Network: Attend career fairs or networking events and connect with faculty members or alumni who work in your field of interest. They can be amazing connections and may be able to offer you advice, mentorship, or even opportunities that may not otherwise be available. 

Remember to be patient and persistent when applying for undergraduate research positions - research positions can be highly competitive, so it may take some time to find the right opportunity. Keep trying, and use any feedback you receive as an opportunity to improve your application materials. Good luck with your search, and I hope this advice helps!
